Graphene-supported NiPd alloy nanoparticles: A novel and highly efficient heterogeneous catalyst system for the reductive amination of aldehydes Bilal Nişancı a b Khadijeh Ganjehyan a Önder Metin a ⁎⁎ Arif Daştan a Béla Török b ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Atatürk University, 25240 Erzurum, Turkey Department of Chemistry Faculty of Science Atatürk University Erzurum 25240 Turkey b Department of Chemistry, University of Massachusetts Boston, 100 Morrissey Blvd., Boston, MA 02125, USA Department of Chemistry University of Massachusetts Boston 100 Morrissey Blvd. Boston MA 02125 USA ⁎ Corresponding author. Fax: +1 617 2876030. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author. Fax: +90 442 2360948. Graphical abstract A novel and highly efficient heterogeneous catalytic reductive amination of aldehydes is described. The recently developed graphene supported NiPd alloy nanoparticle (G-NiPd) catalyst using ammonia borane (AB) as a green, stable and safe hydrogen donor was used in a water/methanol mixture (v/v=2/3) under ambient conditions. The catalytic system was successfully applied in the reductive amination of various substituted aldehydes with amines and the corresponding products were obtained in (up to) 99% yield in 6h. The G-NiPd catalyst could be recycled up to five times without any significant loss in the product yield. Keywords NiPd alloy nanoparticles Reduced graphene oxide Reductive amination Reusable catalyst One-pot synthesis 1 Introduction Due to their basicity, nucleophilicity and biological activity, amines possess special importance in chemical and biological systems. There are numerous natural products including amino acids, nucleic acids, alkaloids and many others that contain the amino motif. Alkaloids represent one of the largest groups of natural products with currently more than twelve thousand known structures [1]. Besides their role in biological systems, amines are important intermediates in the production of fine chemicals, drugs, pesticides, dyes, polymers, resins, solvents, textile additives, disinfectants, rubber stabilisers, corrosion inhibitors, pigments, detergents, and plastics [2]. Due to their importance, several methods have been developed for the preparation of amines. Among others, these include the reduction of nitrogen containing functional groups such as nitro [3], nitrile [4], azide [5,6], and carboxamide [7,8] derivatives (Scheme 1 ). The alkylation of ammonia is also a general method for the synthesis of primary or secondary amines [9], however, over-alkylation often occurs as a side reaction. The Curtius [10] or Hofmann [11,12] rearrangements of carboxylic acid derivatives, and hydro amination [13–16] of alkenes, alkynes or allenes are also well-known protocols for the construction of various amine derivatives. All of the above mentioned methods have several drawbacks; harsh reaction conditions, commercially unavailable starting materials, by-product formation, low yield and often insufficient selectivity [17]. Furthermore; many of these methods do not conform to the principles of sustainable industrial practice. Therefore, the development of novel and efficient methods for the preparation of amines still present significant challenges in organic synthesis. Among the classical methods reductive amination, the reaction of an aldehyde or ketone with ammonia or amine in presence of a reducing agent, carries the greatest potential for the development of environmentally benign methods for the synthesis of amines [18,19]. This versatile method can be carried out in a one-pot reaction without the isolation of the often unstable intermediates (Scheme 1). In the case of reductive amination, the selection of the reducing agent is a crucial factor in determining the success of the reaction. A variety of reducing agents have been used in such reactions including NaBH4 [20–22], NaBH3CN [23], NaBH(OAc)3 [24], Et3SiH [25,26], HCOONH4 [27,28] amine borane derivatives such as NH3BH3 in the presence of Lewis acids [29], borane-pyridine [30], dimethylamine-BH3 [31], t-BuMeiPrN-BH3 [32], benzylamine-BH3 [33], 2-picoline-BH3 [34]. In addition to the reducing agent, the catalyst is also a key aspect of the reductive amination. To date organosilyl [25,26,35] or transition metal catalyzed [36–38] direct reductive amination and heterogeneous palladium-catalyzed [39–44] methods have been developed in recent years (See ESI, Table S1). Aside from these critical components the application of water or other eco-friendly solvents as a reaction medium for the development of catalytic protocols have attracted extended interest [7,8,45–47]. In this respect, we have recently reported the synthesis of monodisperse NiPd alloy nanoparticles (NPs) and their assembly on graphene (G). The application of this catalyst in the transfer hydrogenation of RNO2 and/or R-CN to R-NH2 by ammonia borane (NH3–BH3, AB) as a hydrogen source has been described in aqueous methanol solutions at room temperature with short reaction times and high yields [48]. It was observed that Ni30Pd70 composition provided the best catalytic performance among all tested ratios of NiPd nanoparticles and graphene was identified as the best catalyst support. In addition, our study was the first application of AB as a hydrogen reservoir in heterogeneous catalytic transfer hydrogenation reactions. In order to extend the application scope of this newly developed catalytic system, herein we report a novel and highly efficient heterogeneous catalytic process for the reductive amination of aldehydes applying the graphene supported Ni30Pd70 alloy NPs (G-Ni30Pd70) as a catalyst and AB as a stable and safe hydrogen donor in water/methanol mixture (v/v=2/3) under ambient conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Nickel(II) acetate tetrahydrate (Ni(ac)2·4H2O, 98%), palladium(II) acetylacetonate (Pd(acac)2), oleylamine (OAm, >70%), borane-tert-butylamine (BTB, 97%), 1-octadecene (tech. grade, 90%), hexanes (99%) were purchased from Sigma–Aldrich®. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Transmission electron microscope (TEM) images were obtained by using FEI Tecnai G2 Spirit BioTwin High-Contrast microscope operating at 120kV. The X-ray diffraction pattern (XRD) was recorded on a Rigaku Miniflex diffractometer with CuKα (30kV, 15mA, λ =1.54051Å), over a 2θ range from 10 to 80° at room temperature. The metal content of the NiPd alloy NPs and G-Ni30Pd70 catalysts was determined by using Leiman series inductively coupled plasma-mass spectroscopy (ICP-MS) after each sample was completely dissolved in aqua-regia (HNO3/HCl: 1/3 v/v ratio). 2.3 Synthesis of NiPd alloy nanoparticles The monodisperse NiPd alloy NPs were synthesized by using our well-established protocol published elsewhere [48]. 2.4 Synthesis of graphene The graphene used in this study was prepared by using well-established two-step chemical route. The details of the graphene synthesis and its structural characterization can be found in our recent reports [49]. 2.5 General methods Reactions were monitored using thin layer chromatography (TLC) using aluminium-backed Merck Silica-Gel 60 F254 plates. Column chromatography was performed using Silica-Gel 60 (Merck). All chromatography was carried out using a combination of n-hexane (bp 40–60°C) and ethyl acetate as an eluent. Preparative TLC was performed using a Silica-Gel 60HF254+366 (Merck). NMR spectra were recorded using a 400MHz Bruker NMR instrument (1H NMR at 400MHz, 13C NMR at 100MHz) in deuterated chloroform unless stated otherwise. All chemical shifts are reported in ppm and J values are quoted in Hz. Optical rotations were measured with a 589nm spectropolarimeter at 25°C. Enantiomeric excesses were determined using HPLC analysis on a Thermo Spectra Analysis HPLC System equipped with a UV detector using a chiral column (Chiralcel OJ, Daicel, Japan) with eluent n-hexane–iPrOH, a flow rate of 1.0mL/min and the detection performed at a wavelength of 254nm. Enantiomeric excess was determined directly from the areas under the appropriate peaks. 2.6 Typical procedure for reductive amination of aldehydes with amines Ni-Pd catalyst (4mg) was suspended in water/methanol (2:3) and sonicated (Branson 1510MTH ultrasonic bath) for 5min in a 100mL thermolysis tube at room temperature. Next, benzaldehyde (0.35mmol) and benzylamine (0.42mmol) were added to the reaction vessel. After 30min AB (0.35mmol) was added to the reaction mixture, and the vessel was closed. The mixture was stirred for 6h at room temperature. After the completion of the reaction, diphenylmethane (0.35mmol) was added as internal standard for the determination of the conversions by 1H NMR. Then the alloy was removed by filtration and washed three times with methanol. Next, the catalyst was allowed to dry for further use. The solvent was removed in vacuo. Finally the crude residue was directly purified by TLC using EtOAc/hexane eluent. 2.7 Typical procedure for reductive amination of aldehydes with chiral amine Ni–Pd catalyst (4mg) was suspended in water/methanol (2:3) and sonicated (Branson 1510MTH ultrasonic bath) for 5min in a 100mL thermolysis tube at 0°C. Then, (S)-1-phenylethanamine (0.42mmol) was added to preactivated alloy and sonicated for an additional 20min at the same temperature. Next, benzaldehyde (0.35mmol) was added to the mixture and sonicated for 10min at 0 °C. Then AB (0.35mmol) was added to the reaction mixture, the vessel was closed, the solution was allowed to warm to room temperature and stirred for 6h. After the completion of the reaction, diphenylmethane (0.35mmol) was added as internal standard for the determination of the conversions by 1H NMR. Then the alloy was removed by filtration and washed three times with methanol. Next, the catalyst was allowed to dry for further use. The solvent was removed in vacuo. Finally the crude residue was directly purified by TLC using EtOAc/hexane. 2.8 Reusability test A typical reusability experiment was started as described in Section 2.6, then when the reaction was completed the catalyst was recovered by filtration, washed with methanol and air dried. Then, a new experiment was initiated by using the recovered catalyst. This procedure was repeated 5 times. Analytical data agree with rac-N-(4-Methoxybenzyl)-1-phenylethanamine. 3 Results and discussion Monodisperse NiPd alloy nanoparticles were synthesized by using our organic-solution protocol reported earlier [48]. A typical synthesis of NiPd alloy NPs include the coreduction of nickel(II) acetate (0.2mmol) and palladium(II) acetylacetonate (0.2mmol) by borane-tert-butylamine complex in oleylamine solution at 100°C. This method yielded the Ni30Pd70 alloy nanoparticles. The composition of the alloy was determined by ICP-AES analysis and its particle size by transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The TEM image (Fig. 1 A) of colloidal NiPd alloy NPs indicates a nearly monodisperse size distribution with an average particle size of 3.5nm. To confirm the alloy structure of NiPd NPs, the powder XRD pattern was studied. Fig. 1B shows the XRD patterns of colloidal Ni30Pd70 alloy and Pd NPs in which a right shift was observed by face centered cubic (fcc)-NiPd alloy NPs as compared to Pd NPs indicating the alloy formation between Ni and Pd. To use monodisperse Ni30Pd70 alloy NPs as catalysts in the reductive amination reactions, they were assembled on the surface of chemically prepared graphene (G-NiPd). A representative TEM image for the G-Ni30Pd70 catalysts (Fig. 1C) suggests that the preparation of the supported nanoparticles did not change significantly either the alloy particle size or the size distribution. The detailed analysis of the TEM images (Fig. 1D) supports the visual observation, the homogenous dispersion of NiPd alloy NPs over the graphene nanosheets without any agglomeration of the alloy particles. The chemically derived graphene was selected as a support material for the Ni30Pd70 NPs in this study due to its beneficial role in organic synthesis owing to its 2D structure and defects that attract organic molecules via π–π interactions [48,60,61]. Additionally, in our previous study, it was experimentally demonstrated that the G-Ni30Pd70 alloy NPs provided far superior performance (high yields during short reaction times) in the hydrogenation of R-NO2 and/or R-CN when compared to conventional supports such as active carbon and nano-size alumina powder [48]. After the catalyst preparation and characterization, our attention turned to the application of the catalyst in a heterogeneous catalytic reductive amination. The reductive amination of benzaldehyde with benzylamine was selected as a test reaction. In the process optimization studies, the effect of various reaction parameters were determined including solvent, temperature, reaction time and catalyst loading to identify the best reaction conditions. The data are summarized in Table 1 . It was observed that the reductive amination reaction takes place without a catalyst, but only with minimal yield in water, and moderate yield in a MeOH–H2O mixture over a fairly long period. The time dependence studies with the G-Ni30Pd70 catalysts revealed that the yield gradually improved over the first 6h of the reaction (Table 1, entries 4–10), when the yield was quantitative (Table 1, entry 13). It is worth mentioning that further increasing the time to 15h did not result in any over-hydrogenation, thus the catalytic system is selective for the preparation of the amines. Graphene-supported Ni (G–Ni) and Pd (G–Pd) were also tested for comparison, respectively. While the reaction proceeded with reasonable yields in both cases (Table 1, entries 11 and 12), the Ni30Pd70 alloy appears superior to the individual components used separately. Based on these optimization studies it was concluded that the catalytic systems provides the best performance in a methanol–water solvent mixture, after 6h when the yield is quantitative (Table 1, entry 13). Applying the above determined optimized reaction conditions the reductive amination of several benzyl amines with various aldehyde derivatives was studied. The results are summarized in Table 2 . The data (Table 2) indicate a moderate substituent effect, in most cases; the target secondary amines were obtained in good to excellent yields depending on substituents on the aldehyde or amine. The relatively moderate yield obtained with α-methylbenzylamine and trimethoxybenzaldehyde (Table 2, entry 13) can be attributed to the sterically hindered starting materials. Next, the reductive amination of a chiral amine, ((S)-1-phenylethanamine) was investigated in order to test whether the catalytic system can successfully preserve the configuration of an existing chiral center when chiral compounds are applied in the process. In the HPLC analysis to determine the enantiomeric purity of the obtained chiral secondary amine the racemic samples were applied as reference. The analysis was carried out employing Chiralcel OJ® column with eluent n-hexane–iPrOH as mobile phase. The results are summarized in Table 3 . As shown, the optical purity of the product secondary amines is identical with that of the starting amines, thus the enantiomeric purity was preserved during the reactions. These data indicate that the method could safely be employed in the reaction of chiral compounds. Since nitrogen containing compounds (e.g., pyridine) can act as catalytic poisons for noble metal catalysed reactions the reusability of the catalytic system was also studied to determine the sensitivity of the G-Ni30Pd70 in amine containing systems. The reductive amination of benzaldehyde with benzylamine was selected as a test reaction. After each run, the G-Ni30Pd70 catalyst was recovered by filtration and was reused without further purification in five consecutive runs. The data, presented in Fig. 2 clearly indicate that the catalyst was recyclable with minimal loss in the yields. Considering the small but likely loss of the catalyst during the filtration and reuse, it can be concluded that the activity of the catalyst remained virtually the same after repeated reactions. It is suggested that the presence of Ni in the alloy helped to alleviate the potential poisoning effect of the amines. Presumably the reaction mechanism includes the initial formation of an addition product by the help of G-Ni30Pd70, which would subsequently undergo dehydration to form an imine. Then the in situ formed imine is hydrogenated by the tandem catalytic system. It is proposed that Pd serves in a dual role; first generate hydrogen by catalyzing the dehydrogenation of AB and then hydrogenate the imine (Fig. 3 ). 4 Conclusions In conclusion, a novel and highly efficient catalytic system for reductive amination was developed. The advantages of the methodology have been demonstrated in the synthesis of secondary amines from aldehydes in G-Ni30Pd70 catalyzed reductive aminations. The presented methodology has the following advantages over currently available alternatives; (i) can be performed in a green solvent (water/methanol) with low catalyst loading at ambient temperature while providing quantitative yields, (ii) there is no need for the application of complicated ligands or additional acid/base, (iii) the catalyst is recyclable, (iv) high product yields and (iv) the catalytic system can be applied in the reaction of chiral compounds. These advantages make this methodology attractive for the development of large-scale industrial synthesis of secondary amines. coredata.dc:description: A novel and highly efficient heterogeneous catalytic reductive amination of aldehydes is described. The recently developed graphene supported NiPd alloy nanoparticle (G-NiPd) catalyst using ammonia borane (AB) as a green, stable and safe hydrogen donor was used in a water/methanol mixture (v/v=2/3) under ambient conditions. The catalytic system was successfully applied in the reductive amination of various substituted aldehydes with amines and the corresponding products were obtained in (up to) 99% yield in 6h. The G-NiPd catalyst could be recycled up to five times without any significant loss in the product yield.
coredata.dc:title: Graphene-supported NiPd alloy nanoparticles: A novel and highly efficient heterogeneous catalyst system for the reductive amination of aldehydes
